lun_bawang: Ali-ali lek maya’ tengeb Padian ineh.
english: Along the banks of the Brunei River, silence reigned.

lun_bawang: “Bura’ peh ali inih?” ki Tuk Pelanuk. Lapen iTuk Pelanuk peh lek sigup nidih em, uten neh peh ieh em, telika rebpun ngepub terutung bang lubang dih meh lek ineh. Serebpu’ peh em, riek-riek meh ieh ku rebpun sigup nidih. Kian, ba peh lek ut nidih lek, meriek peh ieh em, but-but meh lek etut neh.
english: “Why is it so quiet here?” Mouse-deer wondered. He took his cigarette and smoked it, the smoke resembling that from smoking a porcupine in a hole. Occasionally, he would cough from the smoke. Who knows, perhaps he smoked so much that he coughed and farted.

lun_bawang: “Aa-hah! Emé’ uih ngukut bua’ emel dai’ dayeh em,” ki Tuk Pelanuk. Lawé keneh peh em, na seburur meh lun mepapu’ neh.* “Ii, iné’ iapeh lek lun inih, na papu’ kinih lek,” ki Tuk Pelanuk.
english: “Aha! I’ll go and scratch the emel fruit upriver,” said Mouse-deer. As he journeyed, he did not meet so much as a single other person. “Hey, where could everyone have gone? I haven’t seen anyone,” said Mouse-deer.

lun_bawang: Iuk peh lek lawé neh emé’ dai’ dayeh, dui, ria’ria’ lek dulun. “Ngudeh lek ideh ineh lek?3”
english: As he advanced upriver, oh, dear, there came the sound of a tumult. “What could they be

lun_bawang: keburi’ Tuk Pelanuk ineh, gang-gang emé’ dai’ dayeh.
english: doing?” said Mouse-deer, walking hurriedly upriver.

lun_bawang: Emé’ ieh em, edui, tetem-tetem teh lek tipan iSapi’ bang tang iBuayeh. Papu’ neh dawa’ pung.
english: “Say, what’s Crocodile doing to Cow?” said Mouse-deer.

lun_bawang: “Ii, kudan iBuayeh iSapi’ ineh?” ki Tuk Pelanuk.
english: “Oh, Crocodile wants to eat one side of Cow’s thigh,” the animals said.

lun_bawang: “Oo, pian kuman selipa tipan iSapi’ iBuayeh ineh,” kedawa’ pung lek.
english: “So, why doesn’t Crocodile just eat the side of Cow’s thigh?” said Mouse-deer.

lun_bawang: “Kai, iko emé’ ninger bisara’ didueh ineh, mutut bisara’ didueh ineh,” kedawa’ pung ni Tuk Pelanuk.
english: “Go, you go hear their case, judge those two’s case,” the animals said to Mouse-deer.

lun_bawang: “Oo, senang ineh,” ki Tuk Pelanuk nedeh. Uten iTuk Pelanuk peh lek sigup nidih em, riekriek meh lek dawa’ iTemecur, dawa’ iKelio, dawa’ iPayo deh neh. Gang-gang lek iTuk Pelanuk emé’ matun ni Buayeh didueh iSapi’.
english: “Oh, I’m happy to,” Mouse-deer said to them. He smoked his cigarette, and Rhinoceros, Ox, and Deer all coughed. Mouse-deer hurried toward Crocodile and Cow.

lun_bawang: “Oo, iko men inih, eca’ Buayeh men. Kudan muh iSapi’ inih?” ki Tuk Pelanuk ni Buayeh.
english: “Oh, it’s you, brother Crocodile. What are you doing to Cow?” said Mouse-deer to Crocodile.

lun_bawang: Awang-awang lek niat iBuayeh ninger ni Tuk Pelanuk nawar neneh eca’ dih. “Oo, eca’ Pelanuk, uih inih melau. Sikel kuman selipa tipan iSapi’ inih, iemo’ ieh na sikel meré. Na patut buri’ neh. Ieh sikel bisara’ atun,” ki Buayeh.
english: Crocodile was overjoyed to hear Mouse-deer call him “brother.” “Oh, brother Mouse-deer, I’m hungry. I want to eat one side of Cow’s thigh, but he’s not willing to give it to me. He says it’s not fair. He wants to hold a hearing first,” said Crocodile.

lun_bawang: “Enun teh inan bisara’ eca’ Buayeh? Em iko peh eca’, melau peh nai em, ngudeh kuman selipa alang-alang, kudeh, na mabud muh dueh-dueh pekop tipan iSapi’? Na peh petap,
english: “What case is there to try, brother Crocodile? You, brother, if you’re hungry, why eat only one side? What, can’t you finish the whole of Cow’s thigh? If that’s not enough, eat Cow’s

lun_bawang: kinan nai peh iSapi’ teburur-teburur dih ieh,” keneh.
english: whole body,” he said.

lun_bawang: Peh ieh, meria’ neh lek dawa’ pung beken ku iTuk Pelanuk ngecuk ni Buayeh kuman ni Sapi’.*
english: At that, the other animals broke out into an uproar because Mouse-deer had told Crocodile to eat Cow.

lun_bawang: “Bura’ keh becé muh, Pelanuk?” ki Sapi’. “Idi uih do’-do’ nenulong ni Buayeh peh em, idi iko ngecuk ni Buayeh kuman pekop tipan kuh, kuman negkuh?” ki Sapi’ lek. Gegkergegker lek ieh ineh, metot kenen iBuayeh.
english: “How could you possibly be so stupid, Mousedeer?” said Cow. “I kindly helped Crocodile, and you tell Crocodile to eat my thigh, to eat me?” said Cow. He trembled, afraid Crocodile would eat him.

lun_bawang: “Kudeng inih,” ki Sapi’. “Emé’ uih, sikel ngirup ebpa’, sier kegkuh em, luti-luti iBuayeh ineh nan bada dai’ ineh. Sék-sék dawar neh mutuh tulong. Idi uih nengun batang dih ret iketed neh. Pengeh dih, idi uih nengun ni Buayeh iné’ bang ebpa’. Bah, kudeng apeh iko
english: “Like this,” said Cow. “I came along, wanting to drink water, and as I looked, there was Crocodile lying prostrate on the sand over there. He was calling out in pain, asking for help. So I lifted that log off his back with my head. After that, I carried Crocodile into the river.

lun_bawang: mala ni Buayeh miek kuman tipan kuh, miek kuman negkuh?” ki Sapi’.
english: Come on, how can you tell Crocodile that he can eat my thigh, can eat me?” said Cow.

lun_bawang: Neriruh peh lek Tuk Pelanuk rayeh-rayeh itengeb dih. “Hahaha, kian, iko luk buki’-buki’ batek inih peh nengiding ni eca’ Buayeh inih em, na keli’ kuh dulun beken, uih peh em, na tu-tu uih menu, mecing maté’ peh em, na teh uih menu,” ki Tuk Pelanuk lek.
english: Mouse-deer laughed loudly on the riverbank. “Ha, ha, ha, no way! You, with your flabby, bulging stomach, lifted brother Crocodile? I don’t know about everyone else, but as for me, I certainly do not believe it. Even when I die, I still will not believe it,” said Mouse-deer.

lun_bawang: “Mebalih iko inih,” keneh. “Kudeng inih peh iko inih Sapi’, ara’-ara’ peh em, mesusa’ teh iko ruen ieca’ Buayeh. Menu muyuh ni Sapi’ inih nengun ni eca’ Buayeh inih lun teluh?” ki Tuk Pelanuk. Perigai’ lek pung-pung beken ungeng.
english: “You are lying,” he said. “You’re doing this, Cow, refusing, unwilling to let Crocodile eat you. Do you believe that Cow carried Crocodile, all of you?” said Mouse-deer. The other animals fell silent one by one.

lun_bawang: “Peh ieh, na lun perigai’ ungeng. Ngelegkan ni Sapi’, eca’ Buayeh. Napeh iko kuman pekop tipan neh. Uih sikel nier, ku metu bala iSapi’ ineh,” ki Tuk Pelanuk ni Buayeh.
english: “Well, then, don’t all be silent. Release Cow, brother Crocodile. Later you can eat his entire thigh. I want to see whether Cow’s words are true,” said Mouse-deer to Crocodile.

lun_bawang: Mawang neh lek niat iBuayeh ninger bala iTuk Pelanuk ineh ni Sapi’ ineh. Peh ieh, ligkan iBuayeh neh lek iSapi’ ineh. Enun, siren peh lek urat tipan iSapi’ ineh em, telika tinapek ku tebpa’ liled teh lek ineh, bagas kitep iBu-
english: Crocodile was delighted to hear Mouse-deer’s words to Cow. And so, then, Crocodile released Cow. The wound in Cow’s thigh looked as though a liled thorn had been driven into it where Crocodile had bitten him.

lun_bawang: “Kudeng inih ieh, eca’ Buayeh. Buri’ iSapi’ ina peh em, inau’ neh ngun iko, kan?” ki Tuk Pelanuk.
english: “How about this, brother Crocodile. Cow said just now that he carried you, right?” said Mousedeer.

lun_bawang: “Éé! Metu,” ki Buayeh.
english: “Yes! True!” said Crocodile.

lun_bawang: “Neh, Sapi’, kudeng apeh un muh ni eca’ Buayeh ina?” ki Tuk Pelanuk ni Sapi’.
english: “Okay, Cow, how did you carry brother Crocodile just now?” said Mouse-deer to Cow.

lun_bawang: “Inau’ kuh ngun nan rier kuh men,” ki Sapi’ lek.
english: “I carried him on my neck,” said Cow.

lun_bawang: “Bah, rua’ ngun ieca’ Buayeh siren tau emung em,” ki Tuk Pelanuk lek.*
english: “Go on, carry brother Crocodile for us all to see,” said Mouse-deer.

lun_bawang: “Mana’ mekun kuh ni Buayeh inih peh. Na keli’ muh tipan kinih ba ét kitep iBuayeh inih?” ki Sapi’ lek.
english: “I can’t carry Crocodile now. Don’t you know my thigh hurts so badly from being bitten by Crocodile?” said Cow.

lun_bawang: “Bah, iko nemala ina, iko nenulong ni eca’ Buayeh. Tau sikel keli’ ku metu keh bala muh atau na,” ki Tuk Pelanuk. Ria’-ria’ meh lek dawa’ pung luk nepemung nan patar liang dai’ puneng Padian ineh.
english: “Come on, you said just now that you helped brother Crocodile. We want to know whether your words are actually true or not,” said Mousedeer. A commotion broke out among the animals gathered on the plain at the Brunei headwaters.

lun_bawang: Peh ieh, neremasang peh lek iSapi’, inun neh peh lek iBuayeh kudeng un neh neneh ina dih em, tub nan bada dai’. Rimud-rimud biring, rimud kabing meh lek iBuayeh ineh.
english: And so, full of resentment, Cow carried Crocodile with his head as he had carried him before and put him on the sand there. Crocodile broke a crooked, lopsided smile.

lun_bawang: “Iapeh batang rayeh luk inau’ muh ngiding ret iketed iBuayeh dih?” ki Tuk Pelanuk ni Sapi’.
english: “Where is that large log that you lifted off Crocodile’s back?” said Mouse-deer to Cow.

lun_bawang: “Oo, dai’ ineh,” ki Sapi’ nicul eceh batang rayeh.
english: “Oh, it’s right there,” said Cow, pointing to a large log.

lun_bawang: “Edui-edui, Sapi’,” ki Tuk Pelanuk. “Na teh uih inih nepernah mala nelun mebalih ret mon-mon Sapi’ em, eleg muh mala, iko nengiding batang luk kirayeh neh ret ku keted
english: “Oh, dear me, Cow,” said Mouse-deer. “I have never, ever called anyone a liar before, Cow, don’t say that you lifted a log of that size from brother Crocodile’s back,” said Mouse-deer,

lun_bawang: ieca’ Buayeh inih,” ki Pelanuk namid-namid keted iBuayeh. Siren peh lek kedih em, na meto-meto meh lek rimud kabing, rimud biring iBuayeh ineh.
english: kicking Crocodile’s back. Crocodile’s unceasing, crooked, lopsided smile widened.

lun_bawang: “Naluk iko ineh, Sapi’. Mebalih iko ineh,” ki Tuk Pelanuk. Mereh tangi’ meh lek iSapi’ ineh ku erur neh nengun ni Buayeh dih.
english: “You are lying to us, Cow. You are a liar,” said Mouse-deer. Cow almost cried from his exhaustion from carrying Crocodile.

lun_bawang: “Sapi’ dé’, metu peh iko nengiding batang ineh em, kidinga’ ieh em, idi iko ngerereng neneh nan keted ieca’ Buayeh em,” ki Tuk Pelanuk ngecuk ni Sapi’.
english: “Cow, if it’s true that you lifted that log, pick it up, and put it on brother Crocodile’s back,” Mouse-deer ordered Cow.

lun_bawang: Siren peh lek kiung iSapi’ kerideng-kerideng teh lek ineh.
english: Cow’s eyes were now tightly closed.

lun_bawang: “Oo, Pelanuk, na kai setuju iko ngenau’ ni Sapi’ kudeng ineh,” kedawa’ Temecur, kedawa’ Kelio, kedawa’ Payo, kedawa’ Baka, kedawa’ Kerubau.
english: “Oh, Mouse-deer, we don’t agree with your doing that to Cow,” said the Rhinoceros, the Oxen, the Deer, the Wild Boar, and the Buffalo.

lun_bawang: “Ineh men. Na’ ba ét tipan kinih kitep iBuayeh ineh,” ki Sapi’.
english: “That’s just it. And my thigh hurts so much from being bitten by Crocodile,” said Cow.

lun_bawang: “Bah, na peh muyuh pung beken setuju, na peh iko setuju Sapi’, ilung neh iko mebalih, atau iko sikel ngigu’ ni eca’ Buayeh. Oo, na miek kudeng ineh. Jadi’, kudeng iko mebalih, miek ieca’ Buayeh kuman tipan muh. Beken mo’ selipa tipan muh, iemo’ pekop tipan muh idi kuman emung burur muh,” ki Tuk Pelanuk.
english: “Well, then, if all you animals don’t agree, and if you don’t agree, Cow, it means that you’re a liar, or you want to embarrass brother Crocodile. Oh, that cannot be allowed. So, if you’re lying, brother Crocodile can eat your thigh. Not only one side of your thigh, but both sides of your thigh, and eat your entire body,” said Mousedeer.

lun_bawang: Enun, pirud-pirud meh lek dawa’ pung ineh. Ba tu neh rimud iBuayeh ku awang niat neh ninger bala iTuk Pelanuk.
english: The animals fell silent. Crocodile smiled gleefully at hearing Mouse-deer’s words.

lun_bawang: “Kapeh ieh Sapi’, iko inih mala luk metu keh, atau naluk ngecekuh ara’ meré tipan muh selipa kenen ieca’ Buayeh?” keburi’ iTuk Pelanuk.
english: “How will it be, Cow? Are you telling the truth, or are you lying because you don’t want to let brother Crocodile eat your thigh?” said Mouse-deer.

lun_bawang: Neremasang peh lek iSapi’ kedih em, nesugar, nebuter, netemueh peh ieh em, inun neh peh lek batang dih em, gieng-gieng meh lek patar liang puneng Padian ineh. Pipet neh peh lek batang rayeh dih nan keted iBuayeh peh em, enun teh, arod-arod lek iBuayeh ku ét keted neh. Lebput-lebput lek arod neh. Sen peh lek
english: Cow, full of resentment, shook his body, flexed his muscles, and stiffened himself, and when he carried that log, the river plain at the Brunei headwaters shook. He threw the large log onto Crocodile’s back, and Crocodile screamed in pain. His cries echoed. Crocodile’s pupils almost jumped and stiffened from the weight of

lun_bawang: kedih em, lé-lé uput lek ilung mateh iBuayeh temueh nan barat batang dih. Nginiat peh lek ieh em, kemu’-kemu’ meh niat neh peh.
english: the log. As he breathed, his breaths were short and shallow.

lun_bawang: “Edui na’, maté lé’! Edui na’ maté lé’!” ki Buayeh lek.
english: “Oh, I’m surely dead! Oh, I’m surely dead!” said Crocodile.

lun_bawang: Siren peh tipan iSapi’ ineh em, enun, darurdarur lek dara’ remuat retnan urat luk kitep iBuayeh dih, ku ieh netemueh, nebutar nengiding batang rayeh dih.
english: As for Cow’s thigh, it was flowing with blood coming out from the wound where Crocodile bit him, because he had stiffened and flexed his muscles to lift that large log.

lun_bawang: Sium meh lek iTuk Pelanuk ni Sapi’. “Bulé’ diko dih Sapi’,” keneh nengapel ni Sapi’. “Oo emung pung luk nepemung nan patar liang puneng Padian inih,* inih putut bisara’ iBuayeh didueh iSapi’ dih peh,” ki Tuk Pelanuk.** *Example (2b) in §5.1.
english: Mouse-deer kissed Cow. “Oh, you poor Cow,” he said, embracing Cow. “Oh, all animals who have gathered on this river plain at the Brunei headwaters, this is my judgment in the case of Crocodile and Cow,” said Mouse-deer.

lun_bawang: “Iko, Sapi’, emé’ ngirup ebpa’. Iko, Busir Kiung, luku neh nai liang batang rayeh ineh pad sukol nai. Sikel peh nai rudap, rudap neh nai tebeco kedangan dih. Sikel peh nai nangi’, nangi’ neh nai. Iemo’ eleg nai ba rayeh tangi’ ko’, merugag kai kuma’ inih,” ki Tuk Pelanuk lek.*
english: “You, Cow, go drink water. You, Abscessed Face, lie there beneath that log as much as you want. If you want to sleep, then sleep all day and night. If you want to cry, then cry. But don’t cry so loudly, please; the rest of us will be annoyed.”

lun_bawang: Pengeh peh lek iSapi’ nemala terima’ kasih ni Tuk Pelanuk peh kedih em, emé’ neh lek ieh ngirup ebpa’. Na teh ieh kio’-kio’ ku kitep iBuayeh dih.
english: After Cow thanked Mouse-deer, he went to drink water. He limped from having been bitten by Crocodile.

lun_bawang: “Ninger muyuh wa’ pung,” ki Tuk Pelanuk teh. “Patad peh tau ret ienih, na tau dat adat. Na tau dat akal kudeng iBusir Kiung ineh. Pun dih peh em, nenguit negkuh pekeca’ ieh. Nenguit negkuh pedinganak. Iuk-iuk peh em, musam neh ieh. Sikel neh ieh kuman negkuh. Do’ luk kudeng inih? Inih peh em, tinulong iSapi’ ieh, tawan iSapi’, edui, sikel kuman selipa tipan iSapi’ neh ieh. Muned luk kudeng ineh keli’ muyuh?” ki Tuk Pelanuk lek.
english: “Hear ye, all animals,” said Mouse-deer. “Let us disperse from here; we are not so vile. We are not foolish like that Abscessed Face. First, he took me as a friend. He took me as a brother. But after a while, he got bored. He tried to eat me. Is this good? As for this, Cow helped him, poor Cow, and, oh, dear, he tried to eat a side of Cow’s thigh. Is that right, do you think?” said Mouse-deer.

lun_bawang: Papag-papag lek dawa’ pung ineh ticu’ deh ku mawang niat peh.
english: All the animals clapped their hands in happiness.

lun_bawang: “Mepatad tau peh. Ret iedih peh sidih em, emé’ iedih neh ieh.* Saga’ ni Busir Kiung maté liang batang ineh,” keneh.
english: “Let us part ways now. Let each return whence he came. Leave Abscessed Face to die beneath that log,” he said.

lun_bawang: Neruked peh lek sebulan, Nepupu peh lek seliakan,
english: A month passed by after that day— Another month, a third, gave way

lun_bawang: Seliakan peh pinupu, Selak peh pikatu, ret pengeh bisara’ iBuayeh didueh iSapi’ dih naté neh iBusir Kiung liang batang dih. Do’ neh lek ulun dawa’ pung. Do’ neh lek tudo iBecuk bang puneng Padian ineh.
english: To a year, which soon was gone, And the years marched on and on from the conclusion of the trial of Crocodile and Cow, and Abscessed Face died beneath the log. So the animals lived in peace, and Monkey dwelt happily at the Brunei headwaters.
